title: Example: Chronic Illness Self-Management
description: Demonstrates a complete Gioia data structure from healthcare research on patient self-management

aggregate_dimensions.name: Managing Chronic Uncertainty
aggregate_dimensions.definition: Overarching construct capturing how patients navigate the ongoing ambiguity inherent in chronic illness management
aggregate_dimensions.theoretical_foundation: Builds on uncertainty management theory (Mishel, 1988) and extends it to daily self-management contexts

second_order_themes.name: Adaptive Routine Building
second_order_themes.definition: Processes through which patients develop and modify self-care practices
second_order_themes.researcher_interpretation: Grouped these concepts because they all involve the iterative development of personalized management strategies that evolve over time

first_order_concepts.name: Selective symptom tracking
first_order_concepts.definition: Focusing monitoring efforts on meaningful indicators rather than comprehensive tracking
informant_terms: just noting the really bad days

example_quotes.quote: I switched to just noting the really bad days because tracking everything was overwhelming. Now I can actually see patterns.

first_order_concepts.coding_note: Distinct from comprehensive tracking; emphasizes strategic selection

first_order_concepts.name: Personalizing medical advice
first_order_concepts.definition: Adapting professional recommendations to fit individual circumstances and preferences

example_quotes.quote: The doctor said to take it with breakfast, but that doesn't work for me. I figured out that taking it at lunch works better for my schedule and my stomach.

first_order_concepts.name: Flexible routine adjustment
first_order_concepts.definition: Willingness to modify established routines when circumstances change
informant_terms: when it feels overwhelming, I change it

example_quotes.quote: Some weeks I can do everything. Other weeks, I just focus on the absolute essentials. You have to be able to adjust.

second_order_themes.name: Navigating Healthcare Systems
second_order_themes.definition: Strategies for accessing and optimizing care within institutional structures
second_order_themes.researcher_interpretation: These concepts share a focus on patient agency in healthcare interactions, particularly overcoming systemic barriers

first_order_concepts.name: Finding doctors who listen
first_order_concepts.definition: Seeking providers who engage with patient perspectives and experiences

example_quotes.quote: I went through four doctors before I found one who actually listened to what I was experiencing instead of just looking at test results.

first_order_concepts.name: Working around insurance barriers
first_order_concepts.definition: Developing strategies to obtain needed care despite insurance limitations

example_quotes.quote: The insurance wouldn't cover the medication, so my doctor and I worked together to find an alternative that would work and be covered.

aggregate_dimensions.name: Reconstructing Identity Through Illness
aggregate_dimensions.definition: How patients integrate chronic illness into their sense of self while maintaining valued aspects of identity
aggregate_dimensions.theoretical_foundation: Draws on identity theory and narrative approaches to illness (Charmaz, 1995)

second_order_themes.name: Redefining Normal
second_order_themes.definition: Processes of establishing new baselines and expectations for daily life
second_order_themes.researcher_interpretation: Grouped because all involve cognitive reframing of what constitutes acceptable or expected functioning

first_order_concepts.name: Accepting the new baseline
first_order_concepts.definition: Coming to terms with changed capabilities and expectations
informant_terms: I had to accept things would be different

example_quotes.quote: There was a point where I stopped comparing myself to how I was before. This is my life now, and I needed to figure out how to make it work.

first_order_concepts.name: Celebrating small victories
first_order_concepts.definition: Finding meaning and satisfaction in accomplishments that might previously have seemed mundane

example_quotes.quote: I used to run marathons. Now a good day is when I can walk around the block without stopping. And you know what? I celebrate that walk.

notes: This is a simplified example showing proper structure format
A real structure would have more concepts and quotes per theme
All quotes are fictional for demonstration purposes
